TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit BounceEase extends System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingFunctionBase

Docs.summary: Represents an easing function that creates an animated bouncing effect.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following graph demonstrates <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase> using different values of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingFunctionBase.EasingMode%2A>, where *f*(*t*) represents the animation progress and *t* represents time.
![BounceEase EasingMode graphs.](~/add/media/bounceease-graph.png "BounceEase EasingMode graphs.")
You can specify how many bounces occur using the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase.Bounces%2A> property and specify how bouncy (how elastic the bounces are) using the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase.Bounciness%2A> property. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase.Bounciness%2A> property specifies the amplitude scaling of the next bounce. For example, a bounciness value of 2 doubles the amplitude of the next bounce during an ease in, and it halves the amplitude of the next bounce during an ease out.
There are several other easing functions besides <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase>. In addition to using the easing functions included in the run-time, you can create your own custom easing functions by inheriting from <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingFunctionBase>.
## XAML Object Element Usage
```xaml <BounceEase .../> ```
## Examples The following example applies a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BounceEase> easing function to a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.DoubleAnimation> to create a bouncing effect.
[!code-xaml[BounceEase_Snippet#BounceEase](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/bounceease_snippet/CS/window1.xaml#bounceease)]

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int Bounces { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.Bounces : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the number of bounces.
Docs.value: The number of bounces. The value must be greater than or equal to zero. Negative values resolve to zero. The default is 3.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property does not include the final half-bounce. [!INCLUDE[DP_ID_field_label](~/includes/dp-id-field-label-md.md)] ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ```

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty BouncesProperty
Public Shared ReadOnly BouncesProperty As DependencyProperty
public: property double Bounciness { double get(); void set(double value); };
member this.Bounciness : double with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies how bouncy the bounce animation is. Low values of this property result in bounces with little lose of height between bounces (more bouncy) while high values result in dampened bounces (less bouncy).
Docs.value: The value that specifies how bouncy the bounce animation is. This value must be positive. The default value is 2.

remarks.format: ## Remarks [!INCLUDE[DP_ID_field_label](~/includes/dp-id-field-label-md.md)] ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ```

.method familyhidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Freezable CreateInstanceCore() cil managed
Protected Overrides Function CreateInstanceCore () As Freezable

Docs.summary: Creates a new instance of the derived class. When creating a derived class, you must override this method.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Animation classes inherit indirectly from <xref:System.Windows.Freezable>. Because of this, you need to override the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BackEase.CreateInstanceCore%2A> method to construct a custom animation object.
## Examples The following example shows a typical implementation of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.CreateInstanceCore%2A>.
[!code-csharp[freezablesample_procedural#CreateInstanceCoreExample](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/freezablesample_procedural/CSharp/freezablesample.cs#createinstancecoreexample)] [!code-vb[freezablesample_procedural#CreateInstanceCoreExample](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/freezablesample_procedural/visualbasic/freezablesample.vb#createinstancecoreexample)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance float64 EaseInCore(float64 normalizedTime) cil managed
Protected Overrides Function EaseInCore (normalizedTime As Double) As Double

Docs.summary: Provides the logic portion of the easing function that you can override to produce the mode of the custom easing function.
Docs.returns: A double that represents the transformed progress.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method transforms normalized time to control the pace of an animation for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingMode.EaseIn> case of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingFunctionBase.EasingMode%2A>.
You only have to specify your easing function for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingMode.EaseIn> case because the implementation of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingFunctionBase.Ease%2A> method transforms `normalizedTime` for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingMode.EaseOut> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.EasingMode.EaseInOut> cases.
